To achieve efficient and selective cycloalkane oxidation, binary catalytic systems had been constructed on the basis of 3D MOFs [Zr6O4(μ 3-OH)4(Metalloporphyrin)2(μ 1-OH)4(μ 1-H2O)4] and Zn(AcO)2. MOFs were prepared to construct limiting domains to suppress diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, and Zn(AcO)2 had been employed as synergistic catalysis sites. Catalytic system constructed by PCN-222-d(Co) and Zn(AcO)2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance. In contrast to T(4-COOCH3)PPCo as homogeneous catalyst, an enhancement from 3.83% to 5.51% was obtained from conversion, meanwhile selectivity was increased from 79.9% to 94.4% in cyclohexane oxidation. Primary source of the excellent performance were inhibition of diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, and enhancement on C-H bonds oxidation with oxidation intermediate R-OOH catalyzed by Zn(II). Synergistic catalysis process and catalytic mechanism were investigated via controlled experiments, radical trapping, and EPR analyses. This study provides a useful reference for oxidative functionalization of cycloalkanes with O2, and a significant contribution for other chemical conversions involving in free radicals. Graphical abstract Conversion and selectivity to partially-oxidized products in cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 were increased simultaneously through synergistic catalysis in binary catalytic systems constructed by PCN-222 with limiting domain and Zn(AcO)2. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cycloalkanes Binary catalytic system Partly oxidation Limiting domain Synergistic catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Utilizing green and available oxidants to oxidize cycloalkanes into valuable chemical raw materials is a perspective way for effective utilization of fossil resources in modern chemical industry [1–4]. Inexpensive cycloalkanes can be converted to high value-added raw materials utilizing O2 as oxidant in chemical industry, which are basic raw materials for the industrial products, such as pharmaceuticals, insecticides, rubber additives and coatings [5–8]. Nevertheless, owing to the inertness of molecular O2 and the high C-H bonds dissociation energy of cycloalkanes, the oxidative transformation of cycloalkanes usually requires high temperature [9–11]. Furthermore, due to some partially-oxidized products being more active than the corresponding cycloalkanes, they are prone to be over-oxidized to acid, leading to a decrease in selectivity. In order to evade deep oxidation of partially-oxidized products and to obtain adequate selectivity, chemical industry often keeps the cycloalkanes conversion at a low level. The cyclohexane oxidation is a very important process in industry, in which cheap cyclohexane is oxidized to high value-added cyclohexanol (A), cyclohexanone (K), acid and other derivatives [12–16]. To avoid deep oxidation of KA oil (cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone) and obtain satisfactory selectivity, the cycloalkanes conversion is usually controlled at 3∼5% and the selectivity of KA oil is kept at 75∼85% [17–20]. The selectivity of KA oil will be greatly reduced by further substrate conversion increases, and it seems to be an impossible mission to simultaneously enhance cyclohexane conversion and selectivity of KA oil. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , to understand the process of cyclohexane oxidation in more depth, the transformation of cyclohexane to oxygenated compounds is commonly separated into three portions. In portion I (Black Arrow), carbon radical is the predominant specie of chain proliferation in cyclohexane oxidation to produce cyclohexyl hydroperoxide [19–21]. Then cyclohexyl hydroperoxide undergoes two parallel oxidation routes to produce KA oil in portion II. One of the routes is the catalytic conversion route (Dark green arrow), which can inhibit the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state. Meanwhile, some fresh cyclohexane can be oxidized into KA oil for the natural ability of cyclohexyl hydroperoxide in C-H bonds oxidation [2,3,19,20,22,23]. And the other route is the thermal decomposition pathway (Blue arrow), in which the diffusiveness of free radicals is disordered. Due to the presence of free radicals diffusion, frequent contact between active free radicals and KA oil is inevitable. Consequently, KA oil may be excessively oxidized in portion III (Red arrow) to form products such as adipic acid, glutaric acid, and other products. This ultimately makes the selectivity of partially-oxidized products come down [24–26]. In addition to the excessive oxidation in portion III, the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state in portion I and portion II is the other cause of selectivity consumption induced by the increased conversion. Because in the environment with the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, the deep oxidation of partially-oxidized products tends to take place. The low conversion of substrate and low selectivity of partially-oxidized products will undoubtedly lead to the energy costs and waste emissions in hydrocarbons oxidation industry, which does not meet the requirements of “Green Chemistry” in modern industry. Accordingly, it is still a challenge to concurrently improve the selectivity of partially-oxidized products and the substrate conversion in hydrocarbons oxidation in current chemical industry [27,28]. As previously noted, the transformation of cycloalkanes with oxygen primarily processes through a free radical diffusion process [20,21,24,29–31]. In the reaction, partially-oxidized products are exposed to active free radicals and are susceptible to be attacked by active free radicals, leading to deep oxidation and the selectivity towards partially-oxidized products coming down. It was believed to be the primary cause for over-oxidation of partially-oxidized products. The second one is that the transformation of oxidation intermediate cycloalkyl hydroperoxide is a thermal decomposition process under disorder state, through which cycloalkyl hydroperoxides can be converted to partially-oxidized products. Additionally, an enhancement in the quantity of reactive radicals to surround partially-oxidized products is triggered by the thermal decomposition of cycloalkyl hydroperoxides, leading to deep oxidation of the partially-oxidized products. At last, high reaction temperature is probably the third cause for the deep oxidation. Clearly, to realize cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 to produce partially-oxidized products in high-efficiency and high-selectivity, it is essential to seriously and rationally take into account the above three points. Only by solving above issues, the over-oxidation of partially-oxidized products can be averted, and the substrate conversion and selectivity to partially-oxidized products in cycloalkanes oxidation can be enhanced concurrently. To avoid selective decrease induced by the increase of conversion in cycloalkanes oxidation, three strategies can be employed and may be effective based on the above considerations. The first strategy is to suppress the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state. The second strategy is to strengthen the process of cyclohexyl hydroperoxide (C6H11OOH) transformation through catalytic route rather than the thermal decomposition under disorder state, and utilize the natural ability of C6H11OOH to oxidize more C-H bonds. The third strategy is to prevent excessive contact between partially-oxidized products and catalysts [32,33]. Many catalytic systems have been developed to solve the issues raised above, including photocatalysis systems [11,34,35], metal oxide particle catalytic systems [4,36], molecular sieve catalytic systems [8,37], and metal-organic framework materials catalytic systems [38–41]. The application of WFeCoO(OH) as catalyst with acetone in cyclohexane oxidation was investigated by Vernekar et al. [4]. The substrate conversion was 24.0% and the selectivity to KA oil was 43.0% during the reaction at 90 °C for 24.0 h. Reisi et al. stated that cyclohexane oxidation at 140 °C for 8.0 h in the solvent of acetonitrile catalyzed by 4.0%Pd-2.0%Ni/KIT-6 utilizing O2 as oxidant [37]. The cyclohexane conversion of 8.6% was observed with selectivity of 70.6% to KA oil. Gu et al. stated that cyclohexane oxidation at 50 °C in the utilization of H2O2 as oxidant and {[Cu(μ 3-cpna)(phen)]·H2O}n as catalyst, in which the conversion of cyclohexane reached up to 20.0% [41]. Most of the aforementioned catalytic systems have focused on improving the substrate conversion without much consideration of the appropriate reaction conditions and target product selectivity. Metalloporphyrins are commonly used to catalyze the oxidation of C-H bonds in hydrocarbon [42,43] because of their outstanding activation characteristics for O2, which in turn can greatly improve the substrate conversion. Based on the above considerations, our group has conducted some preliminary exploration experiments employing binary catalytic systems in attempt to enhance the catalytic conversion of cycloalkyl hydroperoxides and effectively utilize their intrinsic oxidation properties [44–46]. The substrate conversion was heightened to 4.4% from 3.9% and the selectivity of KA oil was notably increased to 97.2% from 88.6% owing to the catalytic conversion of cycloalkyl hydroperoxides. Meanwhile, the synergistic catalysis of bimetallic centers was carried out using cyclohexyl hydroperoxides as secondary oxidants [45]. Consequently, it is a feasible protocol to achieve the simultaneous improvement of substrate conversion and selectivity to partially-oxidized products via synergistic mode of binary catalytic systems. Metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) are crystalline materials with periodic mesh structure formed by self-assembled linkages containing oxygen or nitrogen and metal nodes, which are an important and new class of porous materials besides zeolites and carbon nanotubes. MOFs have the advantages of structural stability, high porosity, and easily adjustable pore structure [47–49]. As the model compounds of cytochrome P-450, metalloporphyrins are a series of transition metal complexes with wide applications, especially in the catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbon compounds with O2 [50]. Inspired by this, MOFs were constructed based on metalloporphyrins and then a large catalyst library of metalloporphyrin-based MOFs was obtained. For the metalloporphyrin-based MOFs, a limiting domain surrounding the metallic centers can be established to suppress the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state. On this basis, binary catalytic systems for cycloalkanes oxidation in high-efficiency and high-selectivity were established in combination with the previous researches of our group on hydrocarbons oxidation in this work. 3D MOFs with porous structure demonstrated in Scheme 2 , were applied as limiting catalytic domains to inhibit the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, and Zn(AcO)2 was employed as synergistic catalysis site to reinforce the catalytic transformation of oxidation intermediate cycloalkyl hydroperoxide. The conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products in cycloalkanes oxidation utilizing O2 as oxidant were enhanced significantly since the limiting domain and synergistic catalysis mode. The increased substrate conversion without consuming the selectivity of partially-oxidized products in cycloalkanes oxidation utilizing O2 as oxidant was an inspiring achievement. The metal-organic framework materials (PCN-224 and PCN-222) were constructed in this work employing porphyrin cobalts(II) (tetrakis(4-carboxylphenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II) (T(4-COOH)PPCo), tetrakis(4-(4-carboxylphenyl)phenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II) (T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo)) as organic ligands and ZrCl4 as the metal nodes. As shown in Scheme 2 [51,52] as a continuation and promotion of our previous work [44–46], the porous structure of MOFs provides a limiting domain to suppress the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state. The utilization of MOFs with zinc salts as binary catalysts simultaneously improved the conversion and selectivity towards partially-oxidized products. In contrast to T(4-COOCH3)PPCo which was applied as homogeneous catalyst, an enhancement from 3.83% to 5.51% was observed from conversion, meanwhile selectivity was increased from 79.9% to 94.4% in the employment of binary catalytic system of PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 in classic cyclohexane oxidation. As far as we know, this work is an innovative and novel case in the utilization of O2 as oxidant to oxidize the C-H bonds of cycloalkanes. Both the conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products were raised concurrently. The strategy proposed could serve as essential guidance for the efficient utilization of hydrocarbons in industry, and also an innovative proposal in academic researches on the functionalization of C-H bonds through the pathway of catalytic oxidation. In this work, the cycloalkanes conversion was enhanced without obvious selectivity consumption mainly through the following four strategies. (1) Suppressing the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state in the limiting domain of 3D MOFs; (2) Catalytic transformation of peroxide facilitated by bimetallic centers; (3) Employing peroxides as secondary oxidant to oxidize more fresh substrates and enhance reaction efficiency through synergistic catalysis. (4) Minimizing the contact of partially-oxidized products with metal sites possessing catalytic properties through heterogeneous catalysis. 2 Experimental section The preparation of porphyrins and metalloporphyrins, some characterization of the synthesized MOFs, the chemicals and materials are described in the Supplementary Material. 2.1 Synthesis of PCN-224-p(Co) PCN-224-p(Co) was synthesized according to the method in the literature [47,51]. T(4-COOH)PPCo (tetrakis(4-carboxylphenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II)) (0.0204 g, 0.024 mmol), ZrCl4 (0.1120 g, 0.48 mmol) and benzene carboxylic acid (0.7816 g, 6.4 mmol) were dispersed in DMF (4 mL) and sonicated in a pressure-resistant glass reaction tube (10 mL). The obtained mixture was heated to 120 °C and kept for 48 h, and then collected the dark red solid power in the mixture employing a centrifuge when the temperature was cooled down to ambient temperature. The dark red power was subjected to washing sequentially using dry DMF (5 × 8.0 mL) and acetone (5 × 8.0 mL). After being dried for 12.0 h in a vacuum oven at 90 °C, a dark red power was obtained as PCN-224-p(Co). 2.2 Synthesis of PCN-224-d(Co) PCN-224-d(Co) was synthesized according to the method in the literature [47,51]. T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo (tetrakis(4-(4-carboxylphenyl)phenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II)) (0.0222 g, 0.024 mmol), ZrCl4 (0.1120 g, 0.48 mmol) and benzene carboxylic acid (0.7816 g, 6.4 mmol) were dispersed in DMF (4 mL) and sonicated in a pressure-resistant glass reaction tube (10 mL). The obtained mixture was heated to 120 °C and kept for 48 h, and then collected the dark red solid power in the mixture employing a centrifuge when the temperature was cooled down to ambient temperature. The dark red power was subjected to washing sequentially using dry DMF (5 × 8.0 mL) and acetone (5 × 8.0 mL). After being dried for 12.0 h in a vacuum oven at 90 °C, a dark red power was obtained as PCN-224-d(Co). 2.3 Synthesis of PCN-222-p(Co) PCN-222-p(Co) was synthesized according to the method in the literature [48]. T(4-COOH)PPCo (tetrakis(4-carboxylphenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II)) (0.0204 g, 0.024 mmol), ZrCl4 (0.2796 g, 1.2 mmol) and benzene carboxylic acid (10.9909 g, 90.0 mmol) were dispersed in DMF (32 mL) and sonicated in a pressure-resistant glass reaction tube (50 mL). The obtained mixture was heated to 120 °C and kept for 48 h, and then collected the dark red solid power in the mixture employing a centrifuge when the temperature was cooled down to ambient temperature. The dark red power was subjected to washing sequentially using dry DMF (5 × 8.0 mL) and acetone (5 × 8.0 mL). After being dried for 12.0 h in a vacuum oven at 90 °C, a dark red power was obtained as PCN-222-p(Co). 2.4 Synthesis of PCN-222-d(Co) PCN-222-d(Co) was synthesized according to the method in the literature [48]. T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo (tetrakis(4-(4-carboxylphenyl)phenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II)) (0.0222 g, 0.024 mmol), ZrCl4 (0.2796 g, 1.2 mmol) and benzene carboxylic acid (10.9909 g, 90.0 mmol) were dispersed in DMF and sonicated in a pressure-resistant glass reaction tube (50 mL). The obtained mixture was heated to 120 °C and kept for 48 h, and then collected the dark red solid power in the mixture employing a centrifuge when the temperature was cooled down to ambient temperature. The dark red power was subjected to washing sequentially using dry DMF (5 × 8.0 mL) and acetone (5 × 8.0 mL). After being dried for 12.0 h in a vacuum oven at 90 °C, a dark red power was obtained as PCN-222-d(Co). 2.5 Catalytic cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 In a polytetrafluoroethylene liner (100 mL), a set amount of catalyst was mixed in cycloalkanes (200 mmol), after which the liner was transferred to an autoclave and then sealed. As the temperature in the reactor reaching up to the set value on the condition of stirring, O2 was introduced into the autoclave to get the set pressure. After stirring for a certain reaction time at the designed reaction temperature and reaction pressure, the autoclave was placed into water to bring the temperature down to ambient temperature, after which the remaining gases were expelled. After opening the autoclave, triphenylphosphine (PPh3) (1.3115 g, 5.0 mmol) was introduced instantly (stirring for 30 min to convert the residual peroxide). To dilute the reaction solution with acetone in a volumetric flask to one hundred milliliters. GC analysis was conducted with 10 mL of diluted solution to calculate the substrate conversion and to determine the selectivity towards alcohols, ketones and hydroperoxides, in which internal standard toluene (0.1843 g, 2.0 mmol) was added into the 10 mL of diluted solution. In GC analyses, a Flame Ionization Detector and a TG-5MS capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) were employed. And HPLC analysis was conducted with 10 mL of the diluted solution to calculate the selectivity to carboxyl acid, in which internal standard benzoic acid (0.0244 g, 0.20 mmol) was added into the 10 mL of diluted solution. In HPLC analyses, an Ultimate 3000 Photodiode Array Detector and an Amethyst C18-H chromatography column (250 mm × 4.6 mm × 0.25 µm) were employed. 2.6 Apparent kinetic studies Cyclohexane had been chosen as the model compound with PCN-222-p(Co) and PCN-222-p(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts to conduct the apparent kinetic study at 120 °C, 125 °C, and 130 °C. And the auto-oxidation had been carried out at 130 °C, 135 °C, and 140 °C. In a polytetrafluoroethylene liner (100 mL), the PCN-222-p(Co) (14.0 mg) or PCN-222-p(Co) (14.0 mg, 0.07 mg/mmol)&Zn(AcO)2 (0.4 g, 2 g/mol) was dispersed in cyclohexane (200 mmol), after which the liner was transferred to an autoclave and then sealed. As the temperature in the reactor reaching up to the set value on the condition of stirring, O2 was introduced into an autoclave to get the set pressure. After stirring for a certain reaction time at the designed reaction temperature and reaction pressure, the autoclave was placed into water to bring the temperature down to ambient temperature, after which the remaining gases were expelled. After opening the autoclave, PPh3 (1.5737 g, 6.0 mmol) was introduced instantly (stirring for 30 min to convert the residual peroxide). To dilute the reaction solution with acetone in a volumetric flask to one hundred milliliters. GC analysis was conducted with 10 mL of diluted solution to calculate the substrate conversion and to determine the selectivity towards alcohols, ketones and hydroperoxides (internal standard, toluene). And HPLC analysis was conducted with ten milliliters of the diluted solution to calculate the selectivity to carboxyl acid (internal standard, benzoic acid). 2.7 Free radical capture experiments CBrCl3, (CH3)3Br and Ph2NH had been applied as capture reagents in the free radical capture experiments. PCN-222-d(Co) (7.0 mg)&Zn(AcO)2 (0.2 g, 2 g/mol), cyclohexane (8.4160 g, 100 mmol) and capture reagents (5.0 mmol) were mixed in a polytetrafluoroethylene liner (50 mL), after which the liner was transferred to an autoclave and then sealed. As the temperature in the reactor reaching up to 130 °C on the condition of stirring, O2 was introduced into the autoclave to raise the pressure up to 1.0 MPa. After stirring for 8.0 h at 130 °C and 1.0 MPa, the autoclave was placed into water to bring the temperature down to ambient temperature, and then the remaining gases were expelled. After opening the autoclave, PPh3 (0.7869 g, 3.0 mmol) was introduced instantly (stirring for 30 min to convert the residual peroxide). The reaction solution was transferred into a glass volumetric bottle (50 mL) and diluted with acetone to 50 mL. The trapped species were confirmed in the utilization of GC and GC-MS, and the inhibited conversions in the free radical capture experiments were obtained too. 2.8 Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analyses In a polytetrafluoroethylene liner (100 mL), PCN-222-d(Co) (14.0 mg, 0.07 mg/mmol)&Zn(AcO)2 (0.4 g, 2 g/mol) were mixed in cyclohexane (200 mmol), after which the liner was transferred to an autoclave and then sealed. As the temperature in the reactor reaching up to 130 °C on the condition of stirring, O2 was introduced into the autoclave to raise the pressure up to 1.0 MPa. After stirring for 4.0 h at 130 °C and 1.0 MPa, 1 mL of the reaction solution was extracted from the autoclave and then 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) was introduced into the obtained solution to carry out the EPR analyses in the microwave frequency of 9.26 GHz with the utilization of JEOL JES-FA200 spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization With the purpose of elucidating the microstructure, the 3D metalloporphyrin-based MOFs obtained in this study were characterized through the utilizations of FT-IR, XPS, PXRD, SEM&EDS, TEM&EDS, BET and TGA techniques. The characterization of 3D MOFs and the corresponding metalloporphyrin through FT-IR were illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). From Fig. 1(a), it can be observed that the strong absorption peak at 1700 cm−1 (the short red dot region) is the characteristic stretching vibration caused by the C=O bonds. And the weaker absorption peak of the C=O vibration in 3D MOFs than in metalloporphyrin is due to the coordination of -COOH with Zr6 cluster [2,3]. The strong absorption peak (the short red dot region) at 1600 cm−1 is the characteristic vibration of the benzene skeleton. The absorption peaks located around 3500 cm−1 and 3000 cm−1 (the yellow region and orange region) are the stretching vibrations generated from the O-H and C-H bonds in metalloporphyrin and the obtained 3D MOFs. The characteristic absorption peaks of metalloporphyrin at the wavenumbers of 1700 cm−1, 1600 cm−1, 1400 cm−1, and 1000 cm−1, were preserved wholly in the obtained catalytic materials. It also indicates the successful preparation of 3D MOFs. As shown in Figs. 1(b) and S1, PXRD measurements were used to verify the crystal structures of 3D MOFs. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the obtained MOFs were consistent not only with the simulated PXRD patterns, but also with reports in the literature [47,48], proving the successful construction of MOFs. In addition to the FT-IR and PXRD analyses, the chemical elements of the MOFs in this work were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) as shown in Figs. 2 and S2. All characteristic elements (a, c in Fig. 2) were observed in the XPS survey spectra, such as element carbon(C), element nitrogen(N), element oxygen(O), element cobalt(Co) and so on. And the valence state of Co 2p was analyzed further by high-resolution XPS as shown in Fig. 2(b, d). Obviously, the binding energies peaks of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 were located at around 796 eV and 781 eV [53–56], both of which composed of three parts, M2+, M3+ and satellites peaks. And M2+ and M3+ were presented in the molar ratio of about 3:1. Therefore, it was concluded that, in the MOF synthesized in this work, the Co element mainly exhibited as +2 valence. SEM, TEM and EDS were employed in this work to characterize the geometric morphology of MOFs. The SEM images in Fig. 3 showed that the geometries of the prepared PCN-222 MOFs were mostly regular stick structure with smooth surfaces at different magnifications, while the geometries of the prepared PCN-224 MOFs were mostly regular cubic structure. This was consistent with the PCN-222 and PCN-224 reported in the literatures [53,57–59], which strongly demonstrates the successful syntheses of MOFs. As can be seen in Fig. 4 , TEM measurements also supported the relatively regular stick morphology of PCN-222 and the relatively regular cubic morphology of PCN-224 [57,60,61]. The representative elements in the prepared MOFs were accurately characterized by the EDS combined with SEM and TEM, including cobalt(Co), zirconium(Zr), carbon(C), nitrogen(N), and oxygen(O), which were uniformly distributed in the prepared MOFs. The superior MOF catalyst in this work is PCN-222-d(Co) with the BET specific surface area of 1528.3752 m2/g, the pore volume of 0.9653 cm3/g and the main distribution of pore widths of 1.27∼1.86 nm and 2.95 nm shown in Fig. 5 (a). The structural attributes of PCN-222 obtained in this research could satisfy the design demands of heterogeneous catalyst materials with enriched pore structures, through which sufficient limiting domains were provided and the radical diffusion in the disordered state could be restrained to promote the catalytic oxidation of C-H bonds by O2 and improve the selectivity for partly oxygenated products. Eventually, the prepared MOFs were evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis under the air atmosphere for their stability. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the loss of weight was less than 10% within 120 °C, which was mostly due to the vaporization of the water which was absorbed on the Zr6 clusters. The MOFs prepared underwent violent thermal decomposition above 350 °C in this work (in air), demonstrating their excellent thermal stability. The high thermal stability was conducive to its effective use in the catalytic oxidation process. Consequently, the structural analyses above revealed that PCN-222 MOFs and PCN-224 MOFs prepared were crystalline materials possessing relatively regular stick and cubic morphologies in this work, respectively. Also the thermal decomposition temperature in air was up to more than 350 °C. And the catalytic center(Co) was uniformly distributed and mainly existed at +2 valence. 3.2 Pre-experiments For the sake of achieving efficient and selective cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 through synergistic catalysis mode, using 3D MOFs and Zn(AcO)2 as the binary catalytic system, with cyclohexane as model substrate, some exploratory studies were conducted in this work. The appropriate reaction temperature was primary question considered in pre-experiments because cycloalkanes underwent unselective auto-oxidation at high temperature, causing the process to become uncontrollable and explosive. As indicated in Table 1 , no significant auto-oxidation was exhibited at 120 °C in utilization of cyclohexane as substrate with the conversion of 0.18% (Entry 3 in Table 1). And as the reaction temperature increased from 120 °C to 130 °C, the conversion of cyclohexane increased to 0.43% (Entry 5 in Table 1), which is an apparent auto-oxidation level in cyclohexane oxidation. Consequently, to avoid the occurrence of non-controllable auto-oxidation and fulfil efficient and selective cycloalkanes oxidation, the reaction temperature should be set lower than 130 °C. Following the temperature ranges determined, the secondary issue in pre-experiments was the viability of achieving efficient and selective cycloalkanes oxidation in limiting catalytic domain of MOFs. As shown in Table 1 (Entry 8∼Entry 10), significant catalytic performance was exhibited when PCN-224-p(Co) was applied to cyclohexane oxidation at 120 °C∼130 °C without no significant auto-oxidation. The cyclohexane conversion was heightened from 0.18% to 3.23%, and the selectivity to partially-oxidized products was 90.8% on the condition of 120 °C. The cyclohexane conversion was somewhat suppressed compared to the metalloporphyrin T(4-COOCH3)PPCo (Entry 11), but the selectivity to partially-oxidized products was heightened from 79.9% to 90.8%. The reason for above phenomenon was mainly due to the inhibition of diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state in the limiting domain of MOFs. A significantly higher conversion was observed in the employment of PCN-224-p(Co) as catalyst with comparison to T(4-COOH)PPCo (Entry 12), and the selectivity of partially-oxidized products was slightly decreased. As indicated in Entry 13 (Table 1), when Zn(AcO)2 was introduced to the cyclohexane oxidation with O2 catalyzed by PCN-222-p(Co), the cyclohexane conversion was increased from 3.23% to 3.90% (Entry 8, Entry 14 in Table 1), and no apparent catalytic performance was exhibited in the utilization of Zn(AcO)2 only as catalyst (Entry 14 in Table 1). In comparison with PCN-224-p(Co), the concurrent improvement of conversion and selectivity utilizing PCN-224-p(Co) and Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts were primarily attributed to the enhancement of catalytic transformation process of cyclohexyl hydroperoxides (R-OOH) rather than the thermal decomposition under disorder state, and the full employment of its natural ability in oxidizing more C-H bonds [44–46]. The obtained result indicated that it was reasonable and feasible to carry out efficient and selective cycloalkanes oxidation in binary catalytic system possessing bimetallic centers. On the basis of above pre-experiments, it was demonstrated that cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 employing 3D MOFs and Zn(AcO)2 as binary catalytic system was very feasible, which could concurrently improve the substrate conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products. This is a strong proof for the practicability and rationality of our research ideas. The third consideration to be explored was the appropriate metal active center. As demonstrated in Table 2 , T(4-COOCH3)PPCo showed the excellent performance (among six metalloporphyrins and corresponding porphyrin without metal center) in cyclohexane oxidation in the utilization of O2 as oxidant with cyclohexane conversion of 3.83% and the selectivity of 79.9% to partially-oxidized products (Entry 3). When anhydrous cobalt acetate was utilized as catalysts, the substrate conversion was not high with the selectivity was not satisfactory (Entry 9). Combined with our previous work [62–64], we considered that the metal center(Co) can activate the molecular oxygen well and convert the inert trilinear oxygen into singlet oxygen, therefore improve the cyclohexane conversion. Consequently, the optimal metal active center was chosen to be Co. 3.3 Catalytic cycloalkanes oxidation in the utilization of MOFs On the basis of preliminary exploration, heterogeneous porous materials (PCN-222 and PCN-224) with monometallic center were constructed employing porphyrin cobalt as structural units. In these MOFs, limiting catalytic domains were constructed based on their porous structures to decrease the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, and their heterogeneous feature was utilized to inhibit the accessibility of partially-oxidized products to metal center(Co) possessing the catalytic performance. As illustrated in Table 3 , when tetrakis(4-carboxylphenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II) (T(4-COOH)PPCo) or tetrakis(4-(4-carboxylphenyl)phenyl)porphyrin cobalt(II) (T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo) were used as catalyst to oxidize cyclohexane, the substrate conversion was only 0.84% or 1.32% (Entry 2, Entry 4 in Table 3), respectively. In comparison with the corresponding ester-based porphyrin cobalt, the selectivity toward partially-oxidized products was significantly enhanced when T(4-COOH)PPCo or T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo was employed to synthesize MOFs(PCN-222 or PCN-224) with a certain pore structure to oxidize cyclohexane (Entry 3, Entry 5, Entry 6∼Entry 9). The reason for the increase in the selectivity was that the pore structure of MOFs(PCN-222 and PCN-224) provides the microscopic limiting domain, which inhibited the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state. And their heterogeneous feature was utilized to prevent the frequent contact between partially-oxidized products and active center(Co), which conformed to original goal and devise in this work. Accordingly, based on above experimental results, the utilization of metalloporphyrin-based MOFs possessing limiting domains as catalyst to oxidize cycloalkanes with O2 in high-selectivity was a useful and sensible strategy. 3.4 Further optimization After the feasibility of cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 in high-selectivity catalyzed by MOFs was established, we further optimized the reaction conditions in terms of catalyst dosage and reaction pressure. As demonstrated in Table 4 , for PCN-224-p(Co), PCN-224-d(Co), PCN-222-p(Co), and PCN-222-d(Co) as catalysts, optimized conversion and selectivity were obtained under 0.07 mg/mmol (catalyst/substrate). When the dosage of MOFs was increased from 0.05 mg/mmol to 0.07 mg/mmol (Entry 1∼Entry 3, Entry 6∼Entry 8, Entry 11∼Entry 13, Entry 16∼Entry 18 in Table 4 ), the cyclohexane conversion was increased with the selectivity towards partially-oxidized products being heightened. Further increasing the dosage of four different catalysts, the conversion was decreased. This was primarily attributed to that the MOFs in higher concentrations were readily to form aggregates [65–68], which greatly reduced the number of active centers in the process of reaction. By optimizing the catalyst dosage, it was found that the catalytic activity of PCN-222-d(Co) and PCN-224-d(Co) synthesized from T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo was superior to that of PCN-222-p(Co) and PCN-224-p(Co). Especially, the cyclohexane conversion was up to 4.21% with PCN-222-d(Co) as the catalyst, and the selectivity of 90.4% toward partially-oxidized products (Entry 18 in Table 4). Consequently, the catalyst dosage was determined as 0.07 mg/mmol (catalyst/substrate). As for optimization on reaction pressure shown in Table 5 , the optimized conversion and selectivity were obtained under 1.00 MPa for both of PCN-224-p(Co) and PCN-222-p(Co). When the pressure was heightened from 0.6 MPa to 1.0 MPa (Entry 1∼Entry 3, Entry 6∼Entry 8 in Table 5), the cyclohexane conversion was heightened to 3.23% and 3.43% with the selectivity of 90.8% and 92.5% towards partially-oxidized products, respectively. No better outcome was exhibited for further increased or decreased oxygen pressure. With lower pressure, the oxidant was insufficient, resulting in a decrease in conversion. However, as the pressure achieving a high level (Entry 4∼Entry 5, Entry 9∼Entry 10 in Table 5), deep oxidation of partially-oxidized products would occur, resulting in a reduction in selectivity of partially-oxidized products. As a consequence, 1.0 MPa was selected as the optimized pressure. On the basis of the above systematic studies, the optimized process for cyclohexane oxidation was obtained employing PCN-222-d(Co) as catalyst. When the catalyst dosage was 0.07 mg/mmol, pressure was 1.0 MPa and temperature was 120 °C, the cyclohexane conversion was 4.21% with the selectivity of 90.4% toward partially-oxidized products. In comparison with T(4-(4-COOH)P)PPCo, it was workable and reasonable to inhibit the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state and accomplish efficient and selective cycloalkanes oxidation utilizing 3D MOFs as catalysts with limiting domains. 3.5 Cycloalkanes catalytic oxidation in the employment of MOFs&Zn(AcO)2 Despite MOFs could offer a limiting domain to suppress the diffusiveness of free radicals in the process of oxidation, some free radicals still escaped from limiting domains and formed R-OOH, which were the primary intermediate products in cycloalkanes oxidation and could be transformed to cycloalkanols (R-OH) and cycloalkanones (R=O) through thermal decomposition under disorder state. The thermal decomposition of R-OOH under disorder state would lead to uncontrollable cycloalkanes oxidation and deep oxidation. In order to avoid them and accomplish efficient and selective cycloalkanes oxidation, Zn(II) was introduced as another active center to transform the R-OOH via a catalytic process. MOFs with active metal center(Co) in the obtained binary catalytic systems were used to activate O2 and inhibit the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state. Zn(II) was introduced to convert R-OOH via a catalytic process and avert thermal decomposition under disorder state. For the sake of establishing the combination of MOFs and Zn(AcO)2, the dosage of Zn(AcO)2 was firstly explored in the utilization of cyclohexane as substrate, and PCN-222-d(Co) and PCN-224-d(Co) as typical MOFs. As seen in Table 6 , when Zn(AcO)2 was employed, the substrate conversion was 0.41%, no significant catalytic performance being exhibited (Entry 1). When Zn(AcO)2 was added with MOFs (PCN-222-d(Co) or PCN-224-d(Co)) to make up binary catalytic systems, both the conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products in cyclohexane oxidation were enhanced notably. In the binary systems constructed by PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 and PCN-224-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2, the cyclohexane conversion showed a trend of increasing and then decreasing with the dosage of Zn(AcO)2 gradually increasing from 0 mg/mmol to 3.0 mg/mmol. The optimal conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products were obtained in both of binary systems at 2.0 mg/mmol of Zn(AcO)2. Further enhancing the dosage of Zn(AcO)2, the substrate conversion decreased. When the concentration of Zn(AcO)2 was too high, it tended to agglomerate into larger particles, leading to a decrease in the amount of active metal centers and a decrease in substrate conversion. In comparison with the corresponding MOFs, cyclohexane conversion was heightened from 4.21% and 4.01% to 5.51% and 5.39% with the selectivity being enhanced from 90.4% and 94.2% to 94.4% and 95.2%, respectively (Entry 2, Entry 5, Entry 8 and Entry 11 in Table 6). With the establishment of binary systems constructed based on MOFs and Zn(AcO)2, the conversion and the selectivity of partially-oxidized products were improved concurrently in cycloalkanes oxidation using O2. This is a satisfactory result in industrial applications and theoretical studies, because partially-oxidized products were readily over oxidized. With the determination of the optimized dosage of Zn(AcO)2, a collection of binary catalytic systems (MOFs&Zn(AcO)2) were constructed. All of binary systems performed satisfying results in the cyclohexane oxidation. In comparison with the corresponding MOFs alone as catalysts, both the conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products were improved in utilization of binary catalytic systems. Utilizing PCN-222-d(Co) and Zn(AcO)2 in particular, the conversion was heightened from 4.21% to 5.51% with the selectivity being improved from 90.4% to 94.4% (Entry 5∼Entry 6 in Table 7 ). Under the comprehensive consideration of conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products, an optimized binary catalytic system was determined as PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2, through which cyclohexane conversion could reach up to 5.51% with selectivity of 94.4% toward partially-oxidized products. Compared with corresponding PCN-222-d(Co) alone, the increased selectivity in the utilization of PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts mostly accounts for that Zn(II) can strengthen the catalytic conversion of R-OOH rather than thermal decomposition under disorder state. This was conducive to acquire higher selectivity to partially-oxidized products [46–48]. With regard to the enhancement on the substrate conversion, it was caused by the efficient employment of R-OOH to oxidize fresh cyclohexane to form partially-oxidized products. As demonstrated in Table 8 , to verify the existence of oxidation of fresh cyclohexane by cyclohexyl hydroperoxides (C6H11OOH) in cyclohexane oxidation with the employment of O2 as oxidant and PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts, cyclooctane was utilized as the representative hydrocarbons to react with C6H11OOH. As shown in Table 8, partially-oxidized products (cyclooctanol and cyclooctanone) were not observed when C6H11OOH in cyclohexane was blended with cyclooctane at 60 °C and N2 atmosphere without catalysts (Entry 1 in Table 8). However, when Zn(AcO)2, PCN-222-d(Co) with monometallic centers and their physical mixture were used as catalysts, partially-oxidized products were detected significantly (Entry 2∼Entry 4), indicating that both Zn(AcO)2 and PCN-222-d(Co) had the ability to catalyze the cycloalkanes oxidation with C6H11OOH as oxidant. The addition of Zn(II) exhibited no significant catalytic performance in cyclohexane oxidation with O2, but strengthened the employment of C6H11OOH to oxidize fresh cycloalkanes, which improved the conversion. On the basis of the above studies and corresponding literatures [21,46,69–72], a synergistic catalysis mode was proposed for the cyclohexane oxidation in limiting catalytic domain of MOFs&Zn(AcO)2. As could be seen in Fig. 6 , cyclohexane was converted to C6H11OOH catalyzed by Co(II) utilizing O2 as oxidant (Stage I), and afterwards the obtained C6H11OOH was applied as a second oxidant to oxidize fresh cyclohexane to form cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone. Both Co(II) and Zn(II) could be utilized as active site possessing the ability in catalytic transformation of C6H11OOH (Stage II). Though synergistic catalysis by PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2, both catalytic transformation of R-OOH and the employment of their natural ability to oxidize C-H bonds were realized. Concurrently enhanced conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products were achieved. Additionally, the synergistic catalysis mode served as a promising, novel and feasible strategy for efficient and selective hydrocarbons oxidation. 3.6 Kinetic study To further investigate the different catalytic performance showed by different catalysis systems in cycloalkane oxidation with O2, kinetic studies were carried out with cyclohexane being the representative model substrate and PCN-222-p(Co) and PCN-222-p(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysis systems. In the apparent kinetic studies, the cyclohexane oxidation was performed with a continuous supply of excess oxygen and maintained under 1.0 MPa with stirring at 600 rpm. The dominant factor in this study that affected the reaction rate was substrate concentration. The pseudo-zero-order, pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order kinetic models were used to fit the conversion data. As indicated by the correlation coefficients shown in Figs. 7 , S3, Tables 9 , and S1∼ S2, it was observed that pseudo-second-order kinetic model was the appropriate model for cycloalkane oxidation in this study, implying that the cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 was predominantly a pseudo-second-order kinetic process. Accordingly, the relational equation of reaction time versus conversion was kt = XA/[CA0·(1-XA)] [73], where t was reaction time, XA was conversion and CA0 was initial substrate concentration. The reaction temperature and the corresponding reaction rate constants k were illustrated in Table 9. The apparent activation energies (Ea) were calculated according to the Arrhenius equation (lnk = - (Ea / R) × (1 / T) + lnk0). The linear fitting was primarily according to lnk and 1/T [73]. Proposed kinetic parameters and the corresponding apparent activation energies (Ea) for the cyclohexane auto-oxidation and catalytic oxidation utilizing PCN-222-p(Co) and PCN-222-p(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts were exhibited in Tables 9 , S1∼S2. It was clear that the Ea for auto-oxidation was 163.91 kJ/mol, and in cyclohexane oxidation utilizing PCN-222-p(Co), PCN-222-p(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts, the Ea decreased sharply to 113.35 kJ/mol and 108.76 kJ/mol. The abilities of different catalytic systems to decrease Ea was extraordinary consistent with their performance in cyclohexane catalytic oxidation. As the Ea was lower, the cyclohexane conversion was higher (Table 10 ). A strong explanation for the performances of different catalytic systems in cycloalkanes oxidation was provided by the study of apparent kinetic. What's more, it also offered a basis for further exploration of the synergistic catalysis mode in binary catalytic systems. 3.7 Substrate compatibility An optimized method of synergistic catalysis for cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 catalyzed by MOFs&Zn(AcO)2 was constructed in this study, utilizing cyclohexane as substrate and PCN-222-d(Co) with limiting domain and Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts. And then the substrate range was extended from cyclohexane to other cycloalkanes such as cyclopentane, cycloheptane, cyclooctane and cyclododecane. As shown in Table 11 , satisfactory conversions and selectivity to partially-oxidized products were obtained for the cycloalkanes involved. For all cycloalkanes, the selectivity towards the partially-oxidized products was more than 94% when PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 were employed as catalysts. As seen in Table 11, with increased number of carbon atoms in cycloalkanes, both conversion and selectivity towards partially-oxidized products, except for cyclopentane, showed an increasing trend, which indicated that the reactivity of cycloalkane and the stability of partially-oxidized products increased with the increased number of carbon atoms in cycloalkanes. The improved reactivity and selectivity of partially-oxidized products with increased number of carbon atoms in cycloalkanes was also a powerful and credible basis for the prediction of the satisfying selectivity to partially-oxidized products when other hydrocarbons were employed as substrates. For the cyclohexane oxidation, which was very important in chemical industry, the conversion reached up to 5.51% with the selectivity of 94.4% to partially-oxidized products. This result was very charming in current chemical industry. With systematic study of substrates compatibility, we proposed that the synergistic catalysis of cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 utilizing PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as the catalysts in the absence of solvent and additive, was a very promising and practical strategy for the functionalization of cycloalkanes. Through synergistic catalysis, the deep oxidation of partially-oxidized products in cycloalkanes oxidation was inhibited efficiently. Excitedly, both conversion and selectivity to partially-oxidized products were heightened simultaneously. 3.8 The consideration of catalytic mechanism The investigation on the mechanism in cycloalkanes oxidation using O2 as oxidant through synergistic catalysis was conducted too in this work. In the mechanism study, the cyclohexane oxidation catalyzed by PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 was employed as model reaction. On the basis of current literature, the cycloalkanes oxidation is a process of free radical diffusion in the utilization of O2 as oxidant [21,74,31]. Consequently, to verify the nature of free radical diffusion in cycloalkanes oxidation in this work, cyclohexane oxidation in the utilization of PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as the catalysts and O2 as the oxidant was carried out in the presence of carbon-radical trap(CBrCl3) or oxygen-radical trap(Ph2NH) [10,18]. When in the presence of CBrCl3, Ph2NH or (CH3)3CBr (at the molar ratio of 5%), the conversion was dramatically decreased from 5.51% to 0.62%, 0.91% or 0.96% (Table S3), which strongly indicated the nature of free radical diffusion of cyclohexane oxidation. What's more, in the quenching experiments utilized CBrCl3 as the radical trap, cyclohexyl bromide and cyclohexyl chloride emerged in the mass spectrometry analyses hyphenated with gas chromatography as illustrated in Figs. S12 and S13, which was a compelling proof for the presence of cyclohexyl radical (C6H11·). To investigate the reaction mechanism, tert-butyl bromide (CH3)3CBr was applied to capture experiments, which was a radical trap. As well as cyclohexyl bromide being detected in this capture experiment, (CH3)3COH was also detected, providing a strongly evidence for the presence of hydroxyl radical (HO·) (Figs. S14 and S15). Furthermore, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technique was used to investigate species of free radicals in this study. It had been illustrated in Fig. 8 , the cyclohexyl radical (C6H11·), hydroxyl radical (HO·), cyclohexyl peroxy radical (C6H11OO·) and cyclohexyl oxygen radical (C6H11O·) were observed by the addition of 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) (a spin trap) in the cyclohexane oxidation catalyzed by PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 employing O2 as oxidant. The free radical species detected in this work were in good agreement with free radical species showed in the literatures [20,21,36]. On the basis of studies on mechanism and exploration on the species of major free radicals, the mechanism in synergistic catalytic oxidation of C-H bonds with O2 as oxidant and PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts was shown in Scheme 3 under the reference of some relevant literatures [21,36,74–79]. As presented in Scheme 3, four main interrelated portions were consisted in the cycloalkanes oxidation catalyzed by PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 utilizing O2 as oxidant. In portion I (black arrow), molecular oxygen was activated by Co(II) in PCN-222-d(Co) followed by the production of high-valence cobalt oxygen species [Co(IV)=O]● ⊕, which could grab hydrogen atoms in C-H bonds to produce hydroxylated cobalt [Co(IV)-OH] and cycloalkyl radicals (R·). The hydroxyl (OH·) of [Co(IV)-OH] in portion I might rebound to R· followed by the formation of cycloalkyl alcohol (R-OH), then be oxidized deeply to cycloalkyl ketone (R=O) and other products. Nonetheless, for the diffusiveness of radicals under disorder state, lots of alkyl carbon radicals R· could escape from limiting domain. Then in portion II (blue arrow), R· which broke away from the limiting domain would react with oxygen, resulting in the formation of important alkyl peroxy radicals R-OO·, and the formation of R-OOH by capturing hydrogen atom from substrates. Under catalysis of Zn(II), the formed R-OOH could be used as an additional oxidant to transform the C-H bond to alcohols and ketones, which not only avoided the thermal decomposition of R-OOH under disorder state, but also enhanced the conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products. The portion III (green arrow) was the same as the portion II, and Co(II) was used as a catalyst center to facilitate the oxidation of C-H bonds through employing the additional oxidant R-OOH. In synergetic catalysis of cycloalkanes oxidation utilizing O2 as oxidant, both portions II and III are very significant and novel steps, which is also the crucial point that we intended to modulate by employing the bimetallic catalytic centers. The portion IV (red arrow) was an inevitable process of transformation in C-H oxidation utilizing oxygen, which processed primarily through the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state and led to the generation of alcohols and ketones at the molar ratio of nearly 1:1. The four portions mentioned above formed an interconnected mechanism network. Through the adjustment of the four portions, cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 could be accomplished efficiently and selectively. 3.9 Comparison with literatures In the end, through a comparison with the current reports on C-H bonds oxidation, the superiority of the combination of PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 was evaluated further. The important and classical cyclohexane oxidation with O2 was selected as the model for comparison. As demonstrated in Table 12 , the protocol developed in this work for cycloalkanes oxidation possessed the following advantages. (1) Without volatile and toxic solvents. (2) Relatively low reaction temperature. (3) Quantitative analysis of the product comprehensively. (4) Increased conversion and selectivity toward partially-oxidized products under the conditions of (1) to (3). (5) No obvious selectivity consumption observed following the increased substrate conversion. The cyclohexane conversion was as high as 5.5% and the selectivity of partially-oxidized products was 94.4% at 120 °C and 1.0 MPa O2 (Entry 1, Table 12). In contrast to T(4-COOCH3)PPCo which was applied as homogeneous catalyst in this work (Entry 3, Table 12), the cyclohexane conversion in the utilization of PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts was enhanced from 3.8% to 5.5% with the selectivity of partially-oxidized products being shifted from 79.9% to 94.4%. The conversion enhancement did not result in excessive consumption on selectivity, which is a fascinating and challenging task in C-H bonds oxidation with O2 due to the substrate are lower active than partially-oxidized products. Additionally, this work was different with other literatures, since this work offered a set of accurate and referential data through quantitative analyses of the low boiling point products (liquid) and high boiling point products (solid) by gas chromatography and high-performance liquid chromatography. Due to the moderate reaction conditions, accurate quantification method and increased conversion without excessive consumption on the selectivity of partially-oxidized products, our protocol can be regarded as a competitive strategy possessing great prospects for hydrocarbons oxidation with O2 in current industry. As well, the proposed study also is an innovative reference for other significant chemical conversions with the involvement of free radicals. 4 Conclusion In summary, binary catalytic systems constructed by 3D metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) possessing limiting domain and Zn(AcO)2, were applied to cycloalkanes oxidation efficiently and selectively. In the obtained binary catalytic systems, 3D MOFs were utilized to activate oxygen and construct limiting domains around metal center to suppress the diffusiveness of free radicals in cycloalkanes oxidation. Zn(AcO)2 was applied to transform the oxidation intermediate (R-OOH) and heighten the substrate oxidation utilizing R-OOH. Both the conversion and selectivity of partially-oxidized products were heightened in cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 through employing PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 as catalysts. In contrast to T(4-COOCH3)PPCo as homogeneous catalyst, the conversion was enhanced from 3.83% to 5.51% with the selectivity of partially-oxidized products was shifted from 79.9% to 94.4% in the typical and significant cyclohexane oxidation of current chemical industry. The excellent catalytic performance of PCN-222-d(Co)&Zn(AcO)2 was mainly ascribed to the inhibition of the diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state in the limiting domain of PCN-222-d(Co), and the intensification on C-H bonds oxidation through employing R-OOH as oxidant. The main advantages of our work compared to current literatures are as follows. (1) Novel binary catalytic systems for hydrocarbon oxidation with O2. (2) Increased conversion and selectivity toward partially-oxidized products simultaneously. (3) Mild and simple condition for hydrocarbon oxidation. (4) Exact quantitative analysis of the products. Hence, this work not only offers an effective and innovative synergistic catalysis model for oxidative functionalization of hydrocarbons utilizing O2 as oxidant, but also enlightens the researches on free radicals in other chemical transformations. Considering our previous studies and related literatures, this work also could be regarded as a reference example in molecular catalysis from homogeneous catalysis to heterogeneous catalysis [86–88]. Because of the relatively poor stability of MOFs in oxidizing atmosphere, more stable catalytic materials with limiting domain would be more suitable for the construction of binary catalytic systems with Zn(OAc)2, such as POFs (porous organic frameworks), porous silicon, porous carbon, and so on, and promote the oxidation of C-H bonds with O2 in high-efficiency and high-selectivity. coredata.dc:description: To achieve efficient and selective cycloalkane oxidation, binary catalytic systems had been constructed on the basis of 3D MOFs [Zr6O4(μ 3-OH)4(Metalloporphyrin)2(μ 1-OH)4(μ 1-H2O)4] and Zn(AcO)2. MOFs were prepared to construct limiting domains to suppress diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, and Zn(AcO)2 had been employed as synergistic catalysis sites. Catalytic system constructed by PCN-222-d(Co) and Zn(AcO)2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance. In contrast to T(4-COOCH3)PPCo as homogeneous catalyst, an enhancement from 3.83% to 5.51% was obtained from conversion, meanwhile selectivity was increased from 79.9% to 94.4% in cyclohexane oxidation. Primary source of the excellent performance were inhibition of diffusiveness of free radicals under disorder state, and enhancement on C-H bonds oxidation with oxidation intermediate R-OOH catalyzed by Zn(II). Synergistic catalysis process and catalytic mechanism were investigated via controlled experiments, radical trapping, and EPR analyses. This study provides a useful reference for oxidative functionalization of cycloalkanes with O2, and a significant contribution for other chemical conversions involving in free radicals.
coredata.dc:title: Cycloalkanes oxidation with O2 in high-efficiency and high-selectivity catalyzed by 3D MOFs with limiting domain and Zn(AcO)2 through synergistic mode
